Chapter 6, Part 9: The Thirty-three Heavens, Part 6
Next, because this exists, that exists. In other words, because there is the other shore, there is this shore.
If there were no other shore, there would be no this shore.
In this way, Heavenly Son!
This is called because this exists, that exists. Because this does not exist, that does not exist. They mutually have birth and each has causes and conditions.
All conditioned dharmas arise from causes and conditions.
The causes and conditions are as follows: ignorance conditions formations, formations condition consciousness, and so forth up to death. It is the same.
Heavenly Son, you should know!
In this way, the World-Honored One explained this Dharma in this palace for five thousand years in the human realm, based on these twelve links of dependent arising.

I will now proclaim a small portion of it for you. It is the same Dharma that the Tathagatas, the Arhats, the Samyak-sambuddhas of the three times, as numerous as the sands of the Ganges River, have expounded, for the sake of the Dharma body.
When that World-Honored Buddha expounded this Dharma, seven koá¹­is of devas exhausted all their afflictions, attained the purity of the Dharma eye.
At that time, the World-Honored One returned to JambudvÄ«pa and, with a mind of great compassion, expounded the Dharma for the sake of humans.
Namely, ignorance conditions formations, up to birth conditions old age and death.
At that time, innumerable and boundless sentient beings, far removed from defilements, exhausted their afflictions and attained liberation in the Dharma.
In this way, the World-Honored One, the Teacher of Gods and Humans, expounded this Dharma for the sake of the gods and humans.

In this way, Åšakra, Lord of the Devas, having extensively expounded the Dharma for the assembly of devas, went to the heavenly palace of the Tuá¹£ita Heaven. Having arrived at the palace, he saw various birds adorned with the feathers and wings of the seven treasures.

In the various lotus ponds, the lotuses in the ponds are of the seven treasures, with the colors of the lotuses various treasure colors, and various bees adorning them, like the sun just rising, with the light of the lotuses adorning the jeweled palace.
Beside the palace is a vaiá¸Å«rya tree, with the light of the tree mutually reflecting each other, causing this heavenly palace to emit a blue light.
The vaiá¸Å«rya tree is of true gold for its leaves, and because of the mutual reflection of the tree leaves, it emits yellow and red light.
Moreover, there is a great light used for adornment, and the palace, gardens, and forests are adorned with various treasures.
The various jeweled palaces, various seven treasures garden forests, and flower trees are used for adornment, and are extremely delightful.
When Åšakra sees them, he gives rise to a rare mind.
In the palace there is a great flower pond, accomplished with the seven treasures, with the water yellow in color like a mass of molten gold, with marvelous adornment.
Various kinds of precious treasures are used for adornment, and birds of various colors are used for decoration.
All the heavenly multitudes play various kinds of heavenly music, sing, dance, and laugh with each other, and go to the great pond, which is called Supreme in All Ways.
The birds in the pond, seeing that the minds of the heavenly multitudes are unrestrained, then speak a verse for the heavenly multitudes, saying:
Just as the vulture does not dwell in the lotus flower,
In this way, in a place of tranquility, evil people should not dwell.
In this way, in a forest of tranquility, how can one indulge in negligence?
Perverse and not in accord with the Dharma, like the cold light of the rising sun,
If one can attain freedom from love and joy, liberation from the many sufferings,
If one can be free from these two dharmas, heavenly pleasures are not true pleasures.
Cultivating meditation and being free from negligence, liberation from the net of desires,
Liberation is called true pleasure, not being deceived by your loved ones.
The World-Honored One abided here first, as well as the practitioners,
You are dragged by desire, you should not stay in this forest.
This palace enjoys heavenly pleasures, impermanent and not lasting long,
If one is free from desire, this is the foremost bliss.
Those who abided in this forest first all enter the foremost place,
If one attains the foremost place, one can cut off all suffering.
The greedy mind likes delicious food, deceived by the greedy mind,
This person should not stay in this tranquil forest.
If one cultivates a tranquil mind, one who delights in purity should stay,
The mind roams in the realm of desire, not staying in the tranquil forest.
If one has a tranquil mind, one should stay in the forest,
Disturbed by the mind of desire, one should not stay in this forest.
Fearing the five causes and conditions, not burned by love,
The pure one who is free from attachment will never fall into the evil paths.
Those who are born will certainly die, the strong are afflicted by illness,
The wealthy and happy have their share of troubles, the young and strong are destroyed by old age;
Enmities and loves must end in separation, unions do not last long,
All phenomena are like this, as the Perfectly Enlightened One has said.
If a person's mind is not deluded in the three realms,
That person will attain peace and should dwell in a quiet forest.
Always being deceitful for the sake of desire, remembering with fear,
That person will not attain the peaceful bliss of the forest.
If a person's mind is pure and they cultivate peace relying on the forest,
That person will find joy in the forest, not one who indulges in desire.
Cultivating a pure mind in the forest, entering the village without moving the mind,
Therefore, dwelling in the forest, one should not dwell in the city.
If a person enters a city or town, they may become confused by lustful thoughts,
Deceitful and impure, but when they return to the forest, they become tranquil again.
Therefore, among the trees, the first and foremost is tranquility,
The place where practitioners should dwell, able to let go of lustful thoughts.
With the faculties and mind tranquil, the practitioner's mind is at ease,
Even a thousand pleasures of Indra cannot compare to this person's mind.
If one attains the bliss of meditative concentration and all pure dharmas,
Even the pleasures of the YÄma Heaven cannot compare to a fraction of this bliss.
Pleasures born from desire are always mixed with suffering,
If one cuts off the bliss of afflictions, it is forever indestructible.
In beginningless birth and death, the afflictions bind the mind like enemies,
If one cuts off these enemies and bonds, desires and pleasures cannot compare.
Pleasures born from desire are impure and have the fruit of suffering,
If one attains the bliss of liberation, that bliss is unequaled.
Relying on the practice of detachment, the practitioner's foremost path,
The bliss born from desire cannot reach the right path.
The initial taste born from desire, the retribution is like fire and poison.
The bliss born from desire always exists in hell.
The initial good taste born from desire, the middle desire is also like this.
In the end, it is tranquil and pure, able to reach a place of peace and bliss.
If the practice is good in the beginning and end, adorned like a loving mother,
How can one abandon right mindfulness and play in the realm of sensual pleasures?
Swirled around by the eddies of desire, always suffering in the middle and end,
How can foolish people give rise to fondness for desire?
Like a poisonous flower of wondrous color, like touching a raging flame,
The bliss of desire is also like this, in the end one experiences great suffering.
Just as a fire is fueled by kindling, its flames cannot be extinguished,
It burns both self and others, desires and pleasures are also like this.
Like a flying moth falling into a fire, it does not see the suffering of being burned,
Desires and pleasures are also like this, foolish people do not realize it.
If a person is attached to desires and pleasures, they are always burned by desires,
Like a moth falling into a lamp fire, the fire of desire surpasses this.
Therefore, abandon desires and harm, always enjoy cultivating wisdom,
Do not engage in negligence, negligence leads to falling into evil paths.
All loved desires and pleasures are deceived by negligence,
After the reward of enjoying pleasures is exhausted, one later falls into the suffering of hell.
That person's good karma is exhausted, deceived by desires,
From heaven to hell, deceived by desire and delusion.
From birth until the end, always cultivate correct contemplation,
Those who contemplate the precepts in their minds will attain tranquility.
Flattery, deceit, and wrong thoughts give rise to the three poisons and attachment.
The water of negligence is very deep, and the desires of women are like water-clothes.
Singing and music move their minds, and the water of love crashes against the rocks.
Covered by the snakes of objects, the waves of the mind flow rapidly.
The great evil of the river of love flows into the realm of the nagas.
Foolish people enter this river and are drowned by the desires of the gods.
Like a terrifying waterfall, the foolish are unaware of being drowned.
Like a foolish bee drinking from a poisonous tree's flowers,
So are the poisonous harms of desire, which the foolish enjoy and crave.
Bees drinking poison may live or die, but there is no one who is not drowned by desire.
Born in the water of the three poisons, blown by the wind of negligence,
The fire of love burns the gods, yet they are still unaware.
Poison grows in the heavens, carelessness is a dense forest,
The place where foolish people play, deceiving their minds with desire.
Carelessness gives rise to desires, grasping without a moment's rest,
These desires are like dreams and illusions, not trusted by the wise.
Although desires are like dreams, dreams are not the cause of hell,
Therefore, abandon all desires and always cultivate pure karma.
Good conduct is supreme, not evil karma,
Thus, bound by good karma, one attains a superior place.
The gods are attached to the pleasures of desire, unable to attain tranquility,
The wise person reaches tranquility, because of being careful.
'At that time, the heavenly bird having spoken this verse for the careless gods, Åšakra, King of the Heaven of the Thirty-three, in this forest again went to another place.

Having arrived at the forest, the forest was adorned with various merits of good karma, the abode of learners and adepts, the dwelling place of the great sage, the World-Honored One, the Tathagata Kakacupa.
At that time, Sakra Devendra, together with countless heavenly beings, making heavenly music, entered the forest together and saw the trees of this forest.

Having entered the forest, the heavenly beings' majestic virtue was all exceptionally superior, like Mount Sumeru among the sixty thousand golden mountains, and Sakra Devendra among the heavenly beings was also like this.

' Indra said:

'In the past, the Tathagata Kakutsunda, the Perfectly Enlightened One, the Supreme Trainer, the Teacher of Gods and Men, together with a hundred thousand monks, all free from doubts, who had seen the Four Noble Truths, attained the two liberations, possessed the six supernormal powers and the four bases of supernatural power, ascended this great palace, in order to bring benefit and peace to the gods and men.
For four months of summer, he resided here, and for the sake of the Thirty-three Gods, he expounded the true Dharma.
Namely:

This is form, this is the arising of form, this is the cessation of form, this is the path to the cessation of form. Feeling, perception, mental formations, and consciousness, the aggregation and gathering, observing the faults and letting go, is also like this.
You should know, Your Majesty!

The Buddha TathÄgata, in this way, gradually taught the Dharma for the sake of the heavenly multitudes who were heedless, arrogant, unaware of the suffering of impermanence and decline, but only attached to the pleasures of desire, and did not know the equal nature of their own characteristics.
At that time, the TathÄgata again taught the subtle Dharma for the sake of the heedless heavenly beings, and reprimanded them with verses, saying:
The root of heedlessness is birth and death, the abode of the heavenly beings.
Drunken with the poison of heedlessness, they sink into the various existences.
If one is able to leave behind heedlessness, one will forever escape the ocean of the three realms.
Heedlessness arises from delusion as its root, blind and dark, unaware of anything.
The arising of light has a root, born from fire and the sun.
The sage says that heedlessness arises from delusion.
The blazing fire of heedlessness arises from the mind.
Deluding foolish people, they lead to the paths of the hells.
Celestial beings and humans who engage in heedlessness are controlled by the colors of women.
When they come together to enjoy themselves, they do not know the suffering of separation from what is loved.
When life is about to end, they experience great suffering right before their eyes.
The retinue of beautiful women also disappears, and all pleasures are ground to dust.
What comes together must separate, and all pleasures come to an end;
Youth will inevitably decline, and all karmic actions will be exhausted.
All sentient beings are bound by good and evil karma,
Like actors performing, each going their separate ways.
Bound by the karma of the actors, they flow and turn in birth and death.
Impermanent karma moves, the wise should not trust it.
Heedlessness is like poisonous harm, one should skillfully abandon it.
If one abandons heedlessness, one will forever cross the ocean of the three realms.

At that time, the Tathagata Kakacanda subdued nine nayutas of careless devas, causing them to be free from carelessness, and with detailed explanations benefited the devas. He then went with the bhikshus and the great assembly to Jambudvipa.
At that time, having spoken these words to the assembly of devas, Indra went to the palace and ascended the jeweled palace.
The Kuthum palace was adorned with innumerable precious treasures, which the devas had never seen before. When the devas saw them, they all joyfully gave rise to a rare mind.
Indra, having seen them, told the assembly of devas:
Have you seen this extraordinary palace?
Never before has there been such supreme adornment.
At that time, the assembly of devas said to the Heavenly King:
Yes, we have seen it.
Indra said to them:
'This jeweled palace was offered by the king of the Heaven of YÄma, with pure faith, to the World-Honored One KÄÅ›yapa.
The light of this palace cannot be seen, and the light of those gods is exceptionally excellent.
Why is this?
Because the gods of the past did not indulge in self-indulgence, unlike you.'
At that time, the assembly of gods knew their own inferiority and abandoned their arrogant minds.
All the gods bowed their heads to the TathÄgata's palace, all gave rise to joy, their complexions were delighted, and their minds became disgusted.

They knew their own karma to be inferior and meager. Some gave rise to the mind of unsurpassed enlightenment, some gave rise to the mind of pratyekabuddha enlightenment, some gave rise to the mind of Å›rÄvaka enlightenment, and some attained unshakable faith in the Buddha. The entire assembly of gods all gave rise to pure faith, joined their palms in respect, and stood to one side.
At that time, Åšakra, Lord of the Gods, entered the Kuá¹­ÄgÄra palace and went to the place where the TathÄgata's lion throne was, where the Dharma was expounded.
The bedding where the Tathagata Kakutsunda lay down was made of vajra and was endowed with various qualities.
At that time, Indra, with a pure mind, threw his whole body to the ground and paid homage to the lion seat, thinking to himself:
This is the place where the Tathagata sat.
With a respectful and reverent mind towards the Tathagata, he rose from the ground and saw verses written on the wall of the scripture hall.
The verses said:
If a person jumps off a cliff, some may not lose their life.
But those who fall into the realm of negligence will all experience suffering.
If a person acts negligently in all their endeavors,
they will never receive any joyful rewards, whether by day or night.
Whether in the mundane world or beyond it, all the blissful dharmas,
negligence can destroy them, therefore one should abandon it.
Those who are not negligent do not die, negligence is the phrase for death;
The most excellent non-negligence will become the lord of the gods.
Negligence is the root of birth and death, while carefulness is the supreme path.
Therefore, abandon negligence and always enjoy heavenly bliss.
If a person wishes for happiness and fears all suffering,
They should abandon negligent conduct, as negligence is like fire and poison.
Negligence and sleep cover people, and the poison of negligence harms the foolish.
They create all kinds of unwholesome karma, and due to negligence, they fall into pits and traps.
Non-negligence is most excellent, while negligence is unwholesome;
Through non-negligence, one attains happiness, while through negligence, one always suffers.
These verses in summary are the root of happiness and suffering.
Knowing this merit, one should skillfully cultivate one's own benefit.

At that time, Åšakra, Lord of the Devas, recited these verses, increasing his respect and reverence. With a pure mind, he again bowed his head to the Lion's Seat. For a long time, he praised non-negligence and reviled negligence in this place, and then left the hall to face the assembly of devas.
At that time, the assembly of devas, seeing Åšakra, Lord of the Devas, all gave rise to respect and reverence, and went to where Åšakra, Lord of the Devas, was.
At that time, Åšakra, Lord of the Devas, fully expounded the verses he had recited to the assembly of devas, and said to the devas:
'These verses were written on the wall of the hall in order to benefit and bring peace and joy to all the sons of the devas.'
When the entire assembly of devas heard this explanation, they all bowed to the World-Honored One and said:
'The TathÄgata, the World-Honored One, the eye of the world, spoke these verses for our sake.'
At that time, the assembly of devas, for a long time not being negligent, again with the sounds of various musical instruments, went with the assembly of devas to the devas who practice subtlety.

The gods of Subtle Conduct, having heard this, will come to this forest with celestial maidens and various musical instruments, producing wonderful sounds, wishing to enjoy themselves with the gods of this forest.

When the gods of Subtle Conduct arrive at this forest, the gods of this forest will lose their right mindfulness and enter into indulgence. With various musical instruments, singing, dancing, and joking, they will approach the great assembly of gods of Subtle Conduct.
Having seen each other, they will all be delighted. In the gardens and forests, jeweled trees and jeweled branches will cover the gardens and forests, and they will enjoy each other.
Until their good karma is exhausted, they will die from the heavens and, following their karma, will transmigrate and fall into the hells, hungry ghosts, or animals.

If one closes the doors to the three evil destinies and is reborn in the human realm in a land of peace and happiness, with gardens, forests, and ponds all complete, always practicing good deeds, greatly wealthy and prosperous, either as a king or a great minister, loved and respected by all people, always delighting in giving, upholding the precepts, and enjoying doing good deeds,
it is due to other karmic causes.

They see with their wisdom of hearing:
There is a place called Wheel of Authority, the twenty-second place.
What karma do sentient beings have that causes them to be born in that celestial realm?
They see with their wisdom of hearing:

Sentient beings who practice good dharmas and are always heedful, who benefit sentient beings with a mind of benefit, who believe in the fruits of karma, who befriend good people, who do not kill, and who do not steal,
If there are birds' nests with young in the trees,
if birds or snakes take the young birds, the person, with a compassionate mind benefiting sentient beings, rescues and liberates them.
How does one not steal?
In others' forests and trees, not even taking a single branch or leaf, nor instructing others to do so.
If walking on the road and seeing fallen fruit on the ground, not taking it or stealing it, if seeing others take it, advising them to let it go.
How does one practice goodness and cultivate giving?
During the rainy season, giving food to the Sangha, if there is a famine, giving food to the sick.

Personally observing precepts, causing others to abide in the precepts, seeing those who abide in the precepts, instructing others to rejoice, explaining the results of karma to other sentient beings.
If one gives to parents, upÄsakas, or those without precepts who are sick, providing them with food, drink, medicine, and necessary items, and also teaches others about the results of karmic actions,
one should not associate with bad friends, live with them, or speak with them.
One should always be able to skillfully control one's physical, verbal, and mental actions, benefiting oneself and others.
When this person's life ends, they will be reborn in the heaven of the thirty-three celestials, in the realm of the wheel of authority.
Having been born in this heaven, due to their good karma, their body will emit light like the full moon.
The realm is adorned and extremely delightful, filled with gardens and forests of the seven treasures.

Arriving at that forest, there is a lotus forest called Flute Amusement, which is five hundred yojanas long and wide. Delicious, colorful, fragrant, and flavorful drinks fill it. The gods drink it and sing, dance, play, and laugh, amusing each other.
At that time, there is a heavenly bird called Right Practice, who sees the celestial sons indulging in carelessness and speaks a verse, saying:
Shamelessness, lack of conscience, laziness, and bad friends,
Are the seeds of hell, abandoned by the wise.
Shameless, lacking conscience, always doing unwholesome actions,
Like a person falling from a high cliff, only later do they realize it.
Greed, delusion, lack of sincerity, a mind without fear,
Confused by jealousy, one cannot be reborn in the heavens.
Drinking alcohol, speaking falsely, the mind firmly attached to greed and desire,
Not believing in the fruits of karma is the cause and condition for hell.
Guarding against the faults of the mind, the evil karma of anger,
Because of sentient beings' evil karma, they fall into the three evil paths.
The mind is brave in creating evil karma, always being driven by desire,
Always engaging in false speech, such a person has no pleasant retribution.
If a person violates the precepts, like a fake jewel or mica,
Because of that person's evil karma, they fall into the three evil paths.
If a person dwells in an evil mind, its darkness is boundless,
If a person takes refuge in the Three Jewels, it is like a great light in the night.
Foolish people engage in negligence, like being intoxicated and deceiving themselves,
Confused by the two kinds of negligence, they transmigrate in the hells.
All in the world, having come into being, must return to cessation,
Just as there is death for the born, they are ultimately inseparable.
Surrounded by carelessness, the ocean of objects grows,
Bound by the chains of craving, playing among the gods.
When the gods are first born, pleasure arises and disappears moment by moment,
Carelessness covers their minds, they do not know the impermanence of change.
Careless and deluded, always delighting in objects,
Because of desire, they are insatiable and always suffer.
Without a moment of mindfulness, for a short time they are not independent,
Driven by craving, sentient beings experience heavenly pleasures.
The ground of craving is extremely violent and evil, with immeasurable mixed thoughts and contemplations,
Playing on the ground of craving, driven by desire.
Just as the fire of hell burns all sinners,
The fire of craving is also like this, burning all gods.
The fire of hunger and thirst burns fiercely, burning all hungry ghosts,
In the animal realm, they harm each other, and in the human realm, they suffer from pursuit.
The fire of craving arises all around, and everything is surrounded by it,
The fire burns constantly, but the world is unable to awaken to it.

' Thus, the heavenly birds spoke these verses to the careless gods. If the gods have previously cultivated wholesome karma, upon hearing this Dharma sound, they will temporarily abandon their carelessness, not drink heavenly wine, and stay far away from the delightful pleasures of the five desires of form, sound, smell, taste, and touch.
They will then enter the gardens and forests to amuse themselves with music, experiencing various pleasures according to their thoughts.
The peaks of sapphirine beryl and malachite in the gardens and forests are adorned with flowing streams, rivers, and lotus ponds, and various colored bees gather there.

In the lotus forest, the leaves are made of beryl, the stems are of crystal, and there are countless bees beyond description. Hundreds of thousands of celestial maidens play and enjoy themselves with the celestial beings.
Due to good karma, they are immersed in the river of love for the various objects and celestial maidens, never waking up.

Thus they play and amuse themselves until their good karmic actions are exhausted, and then they die and transmigrate according to their karma, falling into hell, the realm of hungry ghosts, or the animal realm.

If they are born among humans, they are born in a place of comfort, are greatly wealthy, have vast minds, delight in practicing the true Dharma, always love wisdom, and love Å›ramaá¹‡as and brÄhmaá¹‡as, and have long lifespans.
This is due to their remaining karma.
Furthermore, the bhiká¹£us know the fruits of karma and observe the abodes of the Thirty-three Celestials.
They see with their wisdom of hearing:
The twenty-third place is called the Moon's Course.
What karma do sentient beings create to be reborn there?
He hears, knows, and sees:

If there are sentient beings who, with a pure mind, practice good karma, skillfully cultivate their minds, create Buddha images or make offerings, wash Buddha images to remove dust and dirt, and polish them,

Or if they see gold and silver images of the TathÄgata, see them with joy, contemplate and admire the merit of the field of blessings, contemplate the merit of the mind, and naturally perfume their minds to practice good karma, their minds are filled with joy, they do not kill or steal.
What does it mean not to kill?

Such a person does not even think of ending the life of any being, does not teach others to do so, does not rejoice when seeing others do it, encourages them not to do it, and makes them abide in the path of goodness, benefiting both themselves and others.
There is also non-killing:

They do not think of killing, even small insects such as those born from moisture in their bedding and cushions, and do not wish to harm their lives. They do not have the intention to kill even tiny insects such as ants. This is called not killing living beings.
What is meant by not stealing?
Such good people practice good deeds without knowing satisfaction. They do not steal anywhere, not even grass, trees, or mud. They do not take themselves and do not teach others to do so.
Even in great heat, they do not deprive others of shade and make others stay in the sun. They themselves enjoy shady places.

Even with their own power, they do not take from others, do not teach others, and when they see others doing so, they encourage them not to do so. Even with regard to small matters such as shade and coolness, they do not steal. They do not steal even the smallest things.
This is called not stealing.
Such people, after death, are reborn in the heaven of the moon's course.
Having been born in that heaven, due to their good karma, they attain the fruits of happiness.
The light universally illuminates like the combined illumination of ten months. The bodies and light of the celestial beings are also like this, pure and immaculate.

When the celestial son is born, all the celestial beings become a hundred times more excellent. His body is radiant, and his temperature is just right. All the other celestial beings see him and love him.
His light surpasses the light of the other celestial beings. His light universally illuminates for ten yojanas, surpassing the light of all precious jewels, due to his good karma.
